title: If my consciousness is just an illusion created by the brain, why should I have a reason to live? - Quora

response.answer_text: ***initial disclaimer: if you’re truly having suicidal/negative thoughts please go talk to someone ASAP. There are tons of reasons to live. Problems never last as long as you make the tiniest of effort to fix them. Please be well** What do you find joy doing? What makes you really really really happy? That’s why. Whether it’s sex or creating a drawing or writing a song (or whatever) those are the reasons worth living. One of the topics that laid it out pretty good for me was Absurdism. It basically states that life is so meaningless and short and we’re so small that killing yourself is ridiculous because your time on the planet is so short anyway. from Wikipedia “Accordingly, absurdism is a philosophical school of thought stating that the efforts of humanity to find inherent meaning will ultimately fail (and hence are absurd) because the sheer amount of information as well as the vast realm of the unknown make total certainty impossible. As a philosophy, absurdism furthermore explores the fundamental nature of the Absurd and how individuals, once becoming conscious of the Absurd, should respond to it. The absurdist philosopher Albert Camus stated that individuals should embrace the absurd condition of human existence while also defiantly continuing to explore and search for meaning. [2] It’s literally an absurd conundrum but it makes so much sense when you realize the point is for you to continually search for meaning. that’s where those small bits of joy come into play. Once you catch what makes you happy you HAVE to do more of it because nothing else matters. If you’re not able to do the things that make you happy you’re wasting your time. Yes there are economic and other practical matters to consider, but even with a full time job you should still be able to eek out 1 to 4 hours a day of happiness in something. And be happy! and keep searching for happy! and as long as you’re curious in things you’ll find happiness. Keep your mind as active as you can handle. If you’re pursing happy things tired is only until you sit in that chair. If you can stay up and watch TV or play videos or other mindless thing way past when you should, imagine if you found something you really loved doing right around that time and started doing it? You’ll get excited and then bam, it’s midnight and you’re answering questions on Quora, 2 hours after you intended to go to sleep. :) please be well. life is amazing. Go to an astronomy center, an art museum, or a science museum and look at some of the achievements people have made. We’re extremely special and lucky to have evolved from some bacteria flying in space to what we’ve accomplished now. Yes there is a lot of negatives but you’re mostly in control of your immediate surroundings. You can get a different job, eat different food, wear different clothes, etc. It’s hard but start small changing the things that you don’t enjoy to the things you do enjoy. Treat yourself to stuff and keep looking for the things you love. As Bukowksi said “Find what you love and let it kill you. Let it drain from you your all. Let it cling onto your back and weigh you down into eventual nothingness. Let it kill you, and let it devour your remains.^*” It sounds morbid, but, if you love writing or drawing or making music and you devote all of your energy to doing it, it sounds pretty awesome to me. <3 ps ^* the quote may not have been from bukowski, but i still like it. It’s on the internet, isn’t everything true here? ;) ‘"It's like my friend Kinky Friedman said," mused Van Dyke Parks. "You've got to find what you love and let it kill you. I don't think any of us should ever forget that."

What if this concept is actually an illusion created by the brain. We as humans have an innate tendency to ignore what we have and to admire and cover what we don't. This idea seems really alluring, but the question is does it matter? Please read into Maslow's Need Hierarchy. According to it what you are asking relates to self actualization needs/goals. Ask yourself if have attained the ones preceding it. Maybe then you will have a better perspective of answering the question yourself.

That’s like asking if your car’s motion is just an emergent property of motionless metal parts energized by gas, why should you drive? You are what you are, and liked it well enough before you found out how you really worked. How does your new knowledge materially change anything?

Consciousness isn’t an “illusion”. Consciousness refers to your experience of neurological activity. This is a self-referential and circular definition, but that’s just how it goes with consciousness. At any rate, if you want to keep having that experience, that’s reason enough to live.

There should be a strong feeling that all life has to survive and evolve it is built in, humans often lose this in early childhood as anxiety develops one takes the other away. The feeling is brain energy efficiency EGMi restores this very aggressively, the feeling of inner-happiness comes with it.
You don’t need reasons to live. Your self makes it very difficult to end your life as the idea of death is your self’s greatest fear. For normal people it is their worse nightmare.
If causes produce effects, and you don’t appreciate the choices you have, you can come back as an animal that would like to have more choices.
No, Consciousness is definitely not an illusion! The matter is derived from consciousness. The outer form is an expression of inner form.
